title: Fork Bomb Timeline: The 10-Second System Killer
scenario: A curious developer finds a cryptic command online and decides to try it: ':(){ :|:& };:' - What could go wrong?

timeline.description: Command entered and executed. Function ':' is defined.
256 processes running. CPU usage spikes to 100%
1,024 processes. System starts lagging. Mouse cursor stutters.
4,096 processes. Terminal becomes unresponsive. Can't type 'killall'
16,384 processes. System completely frozen. Keyboard doesn't respond.
Process table full. Can't start any new programs. Can't even log in from another terminal.
Developer realizes the mistake. Tries Ctrl+C. Nothing happens. System is dead.
Developer holds power button. Hard reboot. All unsaved work lost.
System reboots. Developer learns: Never run commands you don't understand.

outcome: Total system freeze in under 10 seconds. Hard reboot required. All unsaved work lost. The fork bomb lived up to its name - it exploded the system with exponential process growth.
lessons_learned: Fork bombs exploit exponential growth - 1 becomes 2, 2 becomes 4, 4 becomes 8...
Modern systems can create thousands of processes per second
Once started, fork bombs are nearly impossible to stop without rebooting
Set process limits with 'ulimit -u 1000' to protect against fork bombs
Never run cryptic commands from the internet without understanding them
Use virtual machines or containers for testing suspicious commands
